name: Interpersonal Therapy (IPT)
summary: A structured, time-limited psychotherapy that focuses on improving interpersonal relationships and social functioning to alleviate psychological distress.
description: Interpersonal Therapy (IPT) is an evidence-based, time-limited treatment originally developed for major depressive disorder. It emphasizes the role of interpersonal relationships, social support, and life events in the onset and maintenance of psychological symptoms. IPT helps patients identify and address problem areas in relationships, such as role disputes, role transitions, grief, and interpersonal deficits. Through structured sessions, patients learn strategies to improve communication, resolve conflicts, and build stronger social support, which in turn reduces psychiatric symptoms.

contraindications: Immediate safety risks requiring crisis intervention
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Safe and well-tolerated; emotional distress may temporarily increase when processing grief or conflicts.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: High—supported by numerous randomized controlled trials and meta-analyses.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Robust evidence for depression and growing evidence for eating disorders, bipolar disorder, and anxiety.

sections.text: IPT works by focusing on the link between interpersonal stressors and psychological symptoms. Therapists help patients improve communication, resolve role disputes, adapt to role transitions, process grief, and build supportive social networks. Improved interpersonal functioning leads to symptom relief.

sections.preparation: Comprehensive assessment including psychiatric and interpersonal history.
procedure: Identify primary interpersonal problem area (grief, role disputes, role transitions, or interpersonal deficits).
Use structured sessions to develop insight and practice interpersonal skills.
Review progress regularly and adjust strategies.
sections.frequency: Weekly sessions (standard); biweekly in maintenance phases.
sections.total_treatment_time: 3–4 months (typical); longer in maintenance or complex cases.

sections.pre_session: Review mood and interpersonal events since last session.
sections.treatment_phase: Focused discussion of interpersonal problem area with skill-building exercises.
sections.post_session: Assign interpersonal tasks or role-play for practice outside therapy.

short_term: Improved coping with transitions or grief

rare: Temporary symptom exacerbation when discussing distressing relationships

relative: Lack of engagement in structured therapy

ideal_candidates: Individuals with depression linked to interpersonal stressors
screening_required: Assessment of interpersonal history and current stressors

studies: Multiple RCTs demonstrate IPT is as effective as CBT and medication for major depressive disorder.
Meta-analyses support IPT in treating postpartum depression and eating disorders.
Evidence supports use as adjunctive therapy for bipolar disorder.
sections.limitations: Requires structured adherence to IPT model; less effective without clear interpersonal focus.

sections.typical_session_cost: $100–$250 per session (varies by provider and setting)
sections.cost_effectiveness: Cost-effective compared to long-term untreated depression or hospitalization.

concurrent_therapies: CBT or DBT for comorbid conditions

sections.children: Adapted versions exist for adolescents with depression (IPT-A).
sections.adolescents: Effective for depression, especially with family involvement.
sections.older-adults: Useful for grief, social isolation, and adjustment issues.

items: IPT is typically manualized, enhancing fidelity and outcome consistency.
Especially effective for depression with clear interpersonal triggers.
Well-suited for integration into primary care and collaborative care models.

items.label: Weissman, M. M., Markowitz, J. C., & Klerman, G. L. (2017). The Guide to Interpersonal Psychotherapy.
Cuijpers P, et al. (2011). Interpersonal psychotherapy for depression: a meta-analysis.
